Clearly, the higher vibrations cause the sound waves to become more compressed, just as higher frequency light waves are smaller.
Thus, the vibrations produced patterns composed of smaller and smaller circles as you went up in frequency.
And if you had the right sound generator, you could hit a frequency so low that the node would cause circles too large to represent on the metal plate. You'd need a larger plate to see the effect.

Compressing the gas and firing it through a plate that has a cymatic pattern to induce a multiple vortex effect and then ionising and heating and further compressing it until it is directed as thrust. Multiple smaller cymatic patterned plates could be used inside the compression chamber or chamber chambers to excite the molecules into phase change.

Radio waves used to pump the plasma, sound waves to shape and direct it and contain it along with magnetic fields could produce a serious thrust. You could probably use the atmosphere as a fuel source thus limiting the weight in fuel for rocket launches.

The magnetic field would probably have to be generated inside the magnetic field in a certain pattern like a toroid, and the cymatics could be generated from inside a all sides of the plasma to hold a stable pattern. But it could be squeezed into a self sustaining disc with a cymatic pattern that is stable like a water droplet is worked upon by sound waves. No real need for crazy low vacuum. Could be directed as a form of propulsion for space travel that is more effective than an ion thruster.

You could possibly even use the frequency of the sun or a derrivative of to contain the plasma and even refine it to avoid an escape of energy much like solar flares escaping from the suns magnetic field.

So what if you introduce a cymatic pattern into a fusion generator to contain the plasma in a certain shape and then heat it with radio waves and a similar shaped magnetic field to contain and increase the heat generated by the plasma to sustain the reaction?

Funny enough, this is one of the first lessons they teach you in audio school. We had a pretty cool experiment, where we calculated the frequency that represented the length of the room. We played that exact frequency from an oscillator and where the node would be, we barely heard anything. One step away where the antinode was, it was loud and clear. Crazy. I urge you to try it!

The representation of the standing waves on a violin plate is inaccurate relative to the real way that it would act because the part of a violin that vibrates doesn't include the corners, and because the sound doesn't reach the back of the violin in the middle, but it reaches it where the sound post is, which is underneath the bridge.

Standing waves are interesting.  I ended up with a standing wave that formed when I used a long piece of corrugated plastic hose with my shop vac.  The sound was unbearable; like a banshee in heat.  I totally eliminated the wave by inserting the steel tape from an old measuring tape down the length of the tube thus disrupting the wave.  The I was able to use this hose for a special tool I had developed.

This same technique is used to locate nodal points on marimba bars when they're being cut and tuned during construction of the instrument.  The bars' suspension strings must attach to each bar at its nodal points so as to not dampen the bars' vibration, and you need to know where those points are so you can notch or drill through the bar to place the strings.  Just sprinkle some sand or salt on the bar and strike it to make it self-resonate, and the grains congregate at the nodal points!

Its an ok explanation, but it sort of misses the most interesting physics (or math I guess) thats going on here. The video explains that we should see nodes, and how those nodes arise, but it misses how we know exactly where those nodes have to be (i.e. what shapes we will see on the plate).

Those shapes are eigenfunctions of the wave equation on a plate. Specifically with neumann BCs on the boundary defined by the plates shape, and a forcing function at the location of the actuator (maybe a delta function if you assume the actuator tip's diameter is negligible). So by solving a fairly straightforward pde we can predict exactly where the nodes will be for any given eigenfrequency and by looking at the eigenvectors we can get a sense of the preferred dimensions of this system.

Admittedly this is a bit uninteresting to most viewers, but I think it is still useful to remember that there is no physics without math, and the math here is quite beautiful.

What if instead of a slinky you have an iron tube. You hold the tube on one end and wave it up and down to create the typical waves. What happens if you were to hit the tube on one end instead of waving it? The other end of the tube would instantly move the same distance. This is the description of longitudinal waves or scaler waves. Transverse wave's propagation speed is C for electricity. Propagation speed for scaler waves is Pi/2*C meaning they are about 1.5 times faster than the speed of light! Cool video....

Very cool experiment! I did an experiment with this in high school (or the Dutch equivalent of high school), and figured out which patterns we should get at different frequencies.  This is the equation we came up with:
cos(m π x / L) * cos(n π y / L) + cos (n π x / L) * cos(m π y / L) = 0
With that formula you can predict where the lines will be at a given frequency. Here's a graph of one of the solutions:
http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=cos%286+%CF%80+x+%2F+1%29+*+cos%281+%CF%80+y+%2F+1%29+%2B+cos%281+%CF%80+x+%2F+1%29+*+cos%286+%CF%80+y+%2F+1%29+%3D+0
